description: plugins/xenserver/networking/etc/xensource/scripts/ovs_configure_vif_flows.py uses lots of hardcoded absolute paths for a bunch of things. We should rely on $PATH being correctly set up. This will make it easier to deal with path transitions (stuff moving between {/usr,}/{s,}bin) as well as help people who have installed an experimental version of stuff in /usr/local.
title: plugins/xenserver/networking/etc/xensource/scripts/ovs_configure_vif_flows.py has lots of hardcoded paths

comments.content: plugins/xenserver/networking/etc/xensource/scripts/ovs_configure_vif_flows.py uses lots of hardcoded absolute paths for a bunch of things. We should rely on $PATH being correctly set up. This will make it easier to deal with path transitions (stuff moving between {/usr,}/{s,}bin) as well as help people who have installed an experimental version of stuff in /usr/local.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~soren

comments.content:
I don't agree with this.

This script is called as a udev hook, and the convention in that environment is not to rely on PATH.  I'm not sure that you even _have_ a PATH.  Even if you do, you don't want a udev hook that suddenly starts running a different version of the vSwitch CLI than the one that matches your running system.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ewanmellor

comments.content:
2011/10/12 Ewan Mellor <email address hidden>:
> This script is called as a udev hook,

Ah, ok. I didn't realise this.

> and the convention in that environment is not to rely on PATH.
> I'm not sure that you even _have_ a
> PATH.

I'm not sure either, but I think you're right.

>  Even if you do, you don't want a udev hook that suddenly starts
> running a different version of the vSwitch CLI than the one that matches
> your running system.

Err.. Right. That's *exactly* why I want it to use the one in
/usr/local. /usr/local is where admins can install things that should
override what is provided by their OS vendor. Everything else will use
the ovs-* commands from /usr/local/sbin if they exist, while this
script will happily keep using the version that is installed in /usr.
